title: Amazon to offer free grocery delivery for US Prime customers
text:
Amazon is dropping its grocery delivery fees for US Prime customers in a move that is likely to tighten its grip on online shopping and steal more market share from supermarkets.

The US retailer said people who had already signed up for its Prime memberships, and were paying an $119 (£92) annual fee, would be able to get tens of thousands of grocery products delivered to their door within one- and two-hour slots without paying any extra.

Up until now, users of the Amazon Fresh online delivery service had paid an additional $14.99 per month.

Stephanie Landry, Amazon's vice president of grocery delivery, said she was expecting the move to be a "game changer", and that the company had "never been afraid to invest in the things that customers love".

Nick Carroll, from Mintel, said Amazon had "always taken the approach that short-term losses for long-term gain is critical to its business strategy".

"The complexities and the cost of delivering online groceries is different from any other online order.

"Amazon is in a privileged position within the retail sector in that a large portion of its business isn't retail. The likes of Amazon Web Services is a highly profitable business, and that feeds in a great deal of capital and investment that it can put into other elements of its business, or indeed run services at a margin that other competitors can't."
description: Amazon is dropping its grocery delivery fees for US Prime customers in a move that is likely to tighten its grip on online shopping and steal more market share from supermarkets.
